item.title: Turkey’s Zorlu to Tackle $4.9 Billion Debt With Cuts, Sales
item.description: One of Turkey’s largest conglomerates is planning to sell assets and lay off staff to ease concern about its $4.9 billion debt burden, underscoring the challenges local companies face from sky-high borrowing costs and entrenched inflation.
item.dc:creator: Kerim Karakaya, Constantine Courcoulas

media:content.media:description: The Zorlu Center complex in Istanbul. Photographer: Nicole Tung/Bloomberg

item.title: Bonnell: France Is a ‘Good Deal’ to Do Investment
item.description: Europe and France are ‘a good deal’ in the context of global geopolitical uncertainties, according to Bruno Bonnell, the Investment Secretary in charge of the plan ‘France 2030’. This comes as French President Emmnauel Macron tallies more than €40 billion of deals at the 8th edition of the "Choose France" summit organized in Versailles. Bonnell spoke with Bloomberg’s Anna Edwards, Kriti Gupta and Guy Johnson on "The Opening Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump to Rally GOP Lawmakers on Elusive SALT Agreement
item.description: President Donald Trump will pay a visit to Capitol Hill on Tuesday to unite a fractured House Republican Conference on a deal over the divisive state and local tax deduction. Joshua Gallu reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Qatar Fund Sees US Outlays Doubling After $500 Billion Pledge
item.description: Qatar’s wealth fund is set to see its annual outlays into the US double in coming years on the back of a $500 billion investment pledge.
item.dc:creator: Joumanna Bercetche, Fiona MacDonald, Nicolas Parasie

media:content.media:description: Mohammed Saif Al-Sowaidi Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

item.title: Citi Sees Weaker Dollar After G-7 Meeting as US Softens Tariffs
item.description: Citigroup Inc. said the dollar could fall further after this week’s Group-of-Seven meeting as global leaders discuss currency policies as part of their trade negotiations with the US.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: A worker counts U.S. dollar banknotes at a currency exchange office.

item.title: Gold Steadies as Haven Demand From Moody’s US Downgrade Fades
item.description: Gold steadied as the haven-demand boost from Moody’s Ratings downgrade of the US faded, and attention turned back to the Federal Reserve’s rate path and easing trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Yihui Xie

item.title: Ooredoo Group CEO on 'Overwhelming' Data Center Demand
item.description: The Group CEO of Ooredoo says demand for data centers is 'overwhelming' and the Qatari telecom operator can't build them as quickly as they should. Aziz Aluthman Fakhroo spoke to Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua at the annual Qatar Economic Forum in Doha about investment, growth opportunities and M&A. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sasol Offsets Strategy to Run Coal Harder With Renewables
item.description: Sasol Ltd. plans to run its flagship plant at full capacity, offsetting the use of coal feedstock by sourcing more renewables as part of a strategy by the world’s top producer of synthetic fuel from coal to improve its business.
item.dc:creator: Paul Burkhardt

media:content.media:description: A worker in the octene and hexene solvents zone at Sasol Ltd.’s main plant which uses gasification to make fuel, in Secunda, Mpumalanga, South Africa, .

item.title: US Stock Rally Set to Stall After Six-Day Run: Markets Wrap
item.description: A six-day winning streak that propelled the S&P 500 to the brink of a bull market is set to pause as investors bet that US stocks will lag the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren

item.title: Ex-JPM Trader Was Fired Unfairly Despite Spoofing, Judge Rules
item.description: An ex-JPMorgan Chase & Co. commodities trader was unfairly dismissed even after a London judge found that “unusual and suspicious” cocoa trades were likely spoofing.
item.dc:creator: Upmanyu Trivedi

media:content.media:description: JP Morgan Chase & Co. signage at the company's offices in New York.

item.title: ECB’s Knot ‘Can’t Rule Out’ Another Interest-Rate Cut in June
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Klaas Knot said another reduction in borrowing costs is possible next month, though stressed that it’s “too early” to make decisions without seeing fresh quarterly forecasts.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

item.title: China Gold Imports Surge to 11-Month High Despite Record Prices
item.description: China imported the most gold in nearly a year last month despite record prices, after heightened demand for the precious metal prompted the central bank to ease restrictions on bullion inflows.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: JPMorgan Makes a Bold Call for Europe Stocks to Beat the US
item.description: The bank sees US stocks falling for rest of year while Europe gains
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani, Michael Msika, Phil Serafino

item.title: Qatar Plans Major Expansion of Physical LNG Trading Volumes
item.description: Qatar plans to significantly boost its liquefied natural gas trading business to complement its expanding domestic production of the super-chilled fuel.
item.dc:creator: Verity Ratcliffe, Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: Saad Sherida Al-Kaabi, Qatar's energy minister, speaks at the Qatar Economic Forum (QEF) in Doha, Qatar, on Monday, May 19, 2025. The fifth annual Qatar Economic Forum will gather government and business leaders in Doha to discuss what’s driving the global economy. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Ivanhoe Mines CEO Robert Friedland on Copper Demand
item.description: Copper is needed now more than ever says Robert Friedland, Founder of Ivanhoe Mines and I-Pulse. He sees new mining opportunities in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Kazakhstan among others. Robert spoke on 'The Pulse with Francine Lacqua' on Bloomberg TV (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: KSA, Qatar & Turkey Ministers Talk Growth & Geoeconomics
item.description: H.E. Ali bin Ahmed Al-Kuwari, Minister of Finance, State of Qatar; H.E. Faisal F. Alibrahim, Minister of Economy & Planning, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia; and H.E. Mehmet Şimşek, Minister of Treasury & Finance, Türkiye, discuss how shifting geopolitical dynamics, trade alliances, and financial strategies are shaping global economic growth with Bloomberg’s Stephen Flanders at the 2025 Qatar Economic Forum, Powered by Bloomberg. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Big Tech Quandary Leaves Equity-Options Pros Divided on Outlook
item.description: Dip-buying in US stocks was a key theme Monday, but the options market is signaling that there’s one crucial area where traders remain far from convinced about the outlook for the next few months: Big Tech.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

media:content.media:description: Some tech giants like Apple, Alphabet, Amazon.com and Tesla are still down this year.

item.title: Japan’s Big Non-Life Insurers Plan to Sell Cross Shareholdings
item.description: Japan’s three major casualty insurers plan to sell a total of about ¥1.37 trillion ($9.5 billion) of cross-held shares in the fiscal year started April in a push to reduce strategic holdings in line with government policy.
item.dc:creator: Nao Sano

item.title: Oil Swings as Iran Leader Throws Fresh Doubts Over Deal With US
item.description: Oil fluctuated sharply after Iran’s supreme leader expressed skepticism over talks with the US, further denting expectations of an agreement over his country’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Yongchang Chin

item.title: ING Sees Potential Carry-Trade Boost Ahead for EM Currencies
item.description: Emerging-market currencies are benefiting from a weaker dollar and they may get a further boost if the US cuts interest rates, attracting more capital into carry trades, according to ING Bank NV.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca

item.title: Pakistan Trims Growth Forecast Amid Trade Headwinds
item.description: Pakistan’s government lowered its economic growth projection for the fiscal year as global trade disruptions and tighter spending conditions by the International Monetary Fund weighed on the South Asian nation’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider

item.title: Ghana at Loggerheads With Afreximbank Over $768 Million Debt
item.description: Ghana, emerging from a bruising debt restructuring process, faces a dispute with African Export-Import Bank, one of its biggest commercial creditors, over whether it should take losses on a $768.4 million liability.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill, Ekow Dontoh

item.title: US Downgrade Sounds Alarm for Hong Kong Funds in Treasuries
item.description: Hong Kong’s pension fund managers have flagged the risk of potential forced selling on their Treasury holdings after a downgrade by Moody’s Ratings of US debt, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie, Echo Wong

media:content.media:description: Source: Excerpt of JPMorgan Chase & Co. report on US holdings by country published on May 14

item.title: QatarEnergy, ConocoPhillips CEOs on Energy & Security
item.description: H.E. Saad Sherida Al-Kaabi, Minister of State for Energy Affairs, State of Qatar and President & CEO, QatarEnergy and Ryan M. Lance, Chairman & CEO, ConocoPhillips discuss global energy supplies and security with Bloomberg’s Francine Lacqua at the 2025 Qatar Economic Forum, Powered by Bloomberg. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Indonesia’s Danantara Eyes Major Overhaul of 800 State Firms Via Mergers, Closures
item.description: Indonesia’s sovereign wealth fund Daya Anagata Nusantara is reviewing the operations of more than 800 state companies and subsidiaries as part of a sweeping overhaul that would likely involve mergers and closures.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: The building housing sovereign wealth fund Daya Anagata Nusantara in Jakarta.

item.title: Tesla Supplier CATL Jumps 14% After Biggest Listing of 2025
item.description: Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Ltd. jumped in its Hong Kong trading debut after the Chinese battery giant wrapped up the world’s biggest listing this year by raising HK$35.7 billion ($4.6 billion) despite being blacklisted by the Pentagon and grinding through geopolitical storms.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: CATL Chairman Robin Zeng strikes a gong at the listing ceremony in Hong Kong. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: Dip Buyers Race to Stocks as Bond Market Shrugs Off US Downgrade
item.description: Stock traders knew it was an ugly setup entering Monday, with futures lower in premarket action and Treasury yields racing higher after Moody’s downgraded the US debt at the very end of last week.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey, Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange on May 19. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Remittance Tax Plan Poses Threat to US Allies in Central America
item.description: A Republican proposal to tax remittances would deliver an economic blow to some of the US’s poorest neighbors, including a close ally of President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Michael D McDonald, Kelsey Butler

media:content.media:description: A MoneyGram transfer location in San Salvador, El Salvador.

item.title: Options Traders Bet Euro Rally Has Further to Run Ahead of G-7
item.description: Traders are growing more confident that the euro’s rally has further to run, with upbeat signals emerging just as Group-of-Seven finance ministers and central bank governors meet in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: New World Asks Banks to Refinance $11 Billion of Loans by June
item.description: New World Development Co. has asked banks to refinance HK$87.5 billion ($11.2 billion) of its loans by the end of June, according to people familiar with the matter, as the cash-strapped builder seeks to quickly shore up its liquidity.
item.dc:creator: Apple Ka Ying Li, Trista Xinyi Luo, Pearl Liu

media:content.media:description: The State Pavilia residential project under construction, developed by New World Development Co., in Hong Kong. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg
